title: Progressive Ocular and Bulbar Weakness in a Case of Myasthenia Gravis: The Story of Mr. Bhatia
clinical_history: Mr. Ramesh Bhatia is a 48-year-old bank manager who presents with a three-month history of gradually worsening double vision, drooping of both eyelids (worse in the evenings), and increasing difficulty with chewing and swallowing solid foods by the end of the workday. He notes voice fatigue during long conversations and increased weakness, especially after exertion or late in the day. In the mornings, he feels relatively well, but as the day progresses, he frequently experiences weakness in his facial musculature, difficulty raising his arms to comb his hair, and muscle fatigue without sensory disturbances. His symptoms improve with short rest and after meals. He denies any respiratory difficulties but feels subjectively weaker over the recent few weeks.

nprs.affected_area: bulbar muscles (dysphagia, dysarthria, neck flexors, mild proximal upper limb fatigue)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged talking, reading, chewing hard foods, physical exertion, late evening hours, emotional stress
picture: [insert diagram of cranial nerves/muscles with particular emphasis on extraocular muscles, bulbar area, and proximal limb muscles]
easing_factors: Short naps, periods of rest, pyridostigmine dose, softer food, cooler environment
past_history: No significant neurological illness. No trauma. Mild hypertension for 4 years, well-controlled.
medical_history: Mild hypertension, no diabetes, non-smoker, no recent infections
personal_history: Lives with spouse, two teenage children. Moderate work-related stress. Enjoys walking in the evenings but activity has reduced due to fatigue. No alcohol use. Adequate sleep, though quality impacted by work stress.
imaging: MRI brain (normal), chest CT to rule out thymoma (pending at time of presentation)
